values: Haven't posted in ages...NY Fashion Week passed, loads of art openings attended, yet this is what I come up with: 1. "Pilgrimage to Puroland" (from Puroland) -- li'l bit of everything that is contemporary Merzbow. noise, drones, beats, guitar-sounding riffs...a lovely cut from a lovely album... 2. "Earth Worms" (from Coma Berenices) -- charismatic psychedelic sludge! 3. "Music Machine" (from Merzzow) -- deep, hot noise!...and psychedelia! 4. "Jimmy Elvins in Traffic" (from Doors Open At 8 A.M.) -- Coltrane-ish! 5. "Sha Mo 3000" (from Sha Mo 3000) -- keeps getting louder and more interesting... I think, contemporary-Merzbow-wise, when speaking of albums as a whole, I am completely digging Puroland (heavy but with riffs) and the more recent Coma Berenices (black, black psychedelia, pure genius). And I need to post a proper art blog.

I'm back into Merzbow again, big time. Five tracks I have had on heavy rotation as of late: 1. "Forgotten Land" (from Merzbeat) -- guitar riffs! drums!...hang on...and noise, lots of noise... 2. "Hen's Teeth" (from Sha Mo 3000) -- proggy! 3. "Mandarin Duck" (from Merzbird) -- heavy metal drumming!...and a cute title! 4. "Alishan" (from Coma Berenices) -- psychedelic! 5. "Sphere pt. 2" (from Sphere) -- super deep bassline!...and noise... I find if I keep the volume tuned low, the expected noisiness blends into a droning, beautiful music, except for the more ambient stuff like Music For Bondage Performance, which I play loudly. Unless I want to really rip it, then I crank the Merzbeat and friends albums up to full blast to really experience it. I think I scare the neighbors when I do this. oh, and Merzbow and boris teamed up and covered "I Am The Walrus" by The Beatles. That's less noisy but pretty cool too...
Today I met the designers of Vena Cava, Lisa Maycock and Sophie Buhai: Two delightful and chic young women who are competing tomorrow morning for the 2007 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund.
Somen noodles with spicy cod roe "pasta sauce" and laver with a side of steamed tofu and iced green tea.

1. boris -- "Flood" (four tracks on the album Flood but I find it far more exhilarating, and interesting, to take 'em in one sitting) 2. Ricardo Villalobos -- "Fitzheuer Zieheuer" (again, can be split into two tracks but the hypnotic rhythm carries over both) 3. Vladislav Delay -- "Anima" (a dense warbling cloud of electronics) 4. Ravi Shankar -- "Raga Ramkali" (has mesmerized me since freshman year in university) 5. Mika Vainio -- "Live @ Invisible Architecture" (the 'atmospherics' man from Pan Sonic)

Jim Dine's "Pinocchio" show at PaceWildenstein in West Chelsea. you have to try to picture these things...most of them are enormous, well over eight feet tall. the Pinocchio with his arms up in the air is like 15 feet tall, easy. in a similar vein to Dine's loving portrayal of this Disney character, I went to Lehmann Maupin Gallery nearby to see the Mr. show, and mister otaku of the Kaikai Kiki set was there! touching up a mural-sized Akihabara painting:

Salad of seedless cucumber, grape tomatoes and albacore with a "dressing" of chili paste (hot!!), lime juice, and soy sauce. I will attempt to semi-regularly update with pictures of food and/or art entries (sometimes, rarely, other things). If this sort of stuff thrills you, do please comment.

Still trying to digest Terry Gilliam's Tideland, which I just saw at the IFC Center...must regain composure before birthday party this evening!... It's not an "easy" film, but it's rather amazing and could be called "genius"... What begins as a traditional Gilliam film (boozed/drugged/smoky haze, loud music, drifting camera, disorientation) morphs into a sun-drenched (and sometimes sinister) slowdown, all depicted through the eyes of an extremely precocious young actor named Jeliza-Rose (I think she was only 10 years old when Gilliam filmed her). We are awarded traces of a grownup Alice in Wonderland that, as adults, makes us very uncomfortable (like I wrote, this is not an "easy" film; parts made me squint and hide my eyes, seriously). But this is the world of a 10-year-old girl, who is innocent and, in that way, stronger than us in resisting (or at least overcoming) the dangers and ultimately surviving this place.

My take on Mutual Appreciation, which I caught this weekend at Cinema Village: I could have made this film, had I continued to live and attempt to work in Austin upon university graduation. No, check that: I could not have made this film, I definitely don't have Andrew Bujalski's talent with the camera (even if that camera is motionless and noninvasive for a great number of shots, more like an onlooker, a scrutinizing eye) nor his resources, though this was a tightly made (and probably tightly budgeted) film. I do believe I could have lived this film, though. So we have a small cast of people who bear resemblance (both in countenance and action) to people I know. Lots of shots of Williamsburg, immediately recognizable. Nearly all dialogue-based, except for the bits where the guy sings at Northsix. It's a group of young post-college people, probably creative types, living and working and feeding off each other's energies to, well, continue living and working. It is a beautiful, relatable story.

A few looks from the Cloak S/S '07 show last evening: Mahhvelous collection, bit rocker and a bit Cold War chic, two things Alexandre Plokhov do with panache to spare. The show, held in this long corrider (like a haunted house, almost) in Soho was quite the scene, full of dark-clad beautiful people bobbing their heads to the pounding industrial soundtrack as the models stalked down the runway at a brisk, intimidating clip.

Like I have any idea what 1/4 of these mean. Do you?

1. boris - "Flood 2" (Flood) 2. boris - "Kuruimizu" (Amplifier Worship) 3. boris - "Farewell" (Pink) 4. boris - "Flood 3" (Flood) 5. boris - "Feedbacker 2" (Feedbacker) bit of a theme going on here?.......

Considering my listening tastes of late (I'll list a "top five" at the bottom of this), I decided a subtle, introspective listening experience would be a nice way to break up the week and close out summer. Last night I went to Monkeytown to the show Emptiness (tagline: "sounds so small you can hear yourself think") to achieve this. I knew going in that CHiKA would be performing alongside one of the musicians and I have come to really dig her sets of late. So that would be promising. The musicians (Bernhard Gal, o.blaat and i8u) and curator/video artist Ilan Katin were new to me, but in an atmospheric setting like Monkeytown I figured they would bring delightful elements to the performance. I wondered whether they would perform on the floor of the main space (amid couches and audience, necessarily) or if they'd remain incognito in the loft control booth overhead (like a DJ booth, I guess). My question was answered upon entering the main room: CHiKA (Chika Iijima) and o.blaat (Keiko Uenishi) sat in front of two laptops in one corner (NW from the doors) and i8u (France Jobin) and Bernhard Gal had a similar setup in another corner (NE this time). In the center of the room, perched on a metal stool, was a channel mixer with multicolored cables going off in seemingly all directions (though mostly to the NW and NE corners, respectively). Katin would perform his bit of the show upstairs. In a vain effort to stay ahead of the trend (but even that dovetails to trendiness itself), I ordered a glass of rose, in Monkeytown's case that would be Prieure Saint-Hippolyte. I burrowed back into the overstuffed couch and, as a hush drew over the crowd, Katin took the floor and announced the show. CHiKA and i8u would begin (and, incidentally, their set would be my favorite of the night): low, almost soothing siren tones from i8u's end, while CHiKA created flashing red lights to mimic. Then, a growing wave of staticky pops and sizzles with an undercurrent of deeep bass accompanied by test patterns of moving white lines and stammering lines of red dots. Eventually, i8u would bring it down to another soothing synth pad element while CHiKA conjured an amorphous white shape that filled the screens until there was nothing left. Bernhard Gal took over next without grandeur, creating several hushed (but crescendoing) bell tones while keeping a terribly bored (or calm?) expression. He provided his own visual accompanyment, a video called "Radio Ears (Textur Two)" of sliding images of urban facades and satellite dishes. The pulsing high tones gradually loudened until...silence! A minute or two of this (the video continued) and Katin took the floor, explaining Gal's machine just died. "Well, actually I am bringing an extremely authentic element to tonight's theme," laughed Gal. But that would be it for him. Katin and o.blaat regrouped as he explained their contribution: apparently she turned her part of the channel mixer into a huge contact mic and would pick up our own atmospheric sounds (clinking flatware, conversations) while Katin would draw food-related concepts on three of the four screens (the fourth would be a slideshow of o.blaat's food photography from the past few years). Seriously. So it began: a hiss and hum from o.blaat's laptop and the people next to me tried drumming their forks on the table, spinning coins, moving their glasses. The returning echoes emitted like roaring white noise from o.blaat's machine. I tried moving the large glass water bottle across the table and received a low growling noise in response. Katin did indeed draw food thoughts: he pasted up a huge clipart file of sashimi-style tuna and drew the words TORTURED FISH FOOD FOR ALL, as one example. And it went on from there... I think the night would have been tighter overall had a) Gal's laptop not quit on him (I was intrigued by his set) and b) the order had shuffled to the more experimental (and furiously louder) o.blaat/Katin set in the lead and (depending on Gal's performance) ending instead with i8u and CHiKA. That way, as the sound emptied from the speakers and evaporated into the air, we would have left a bit more content, or more full if you will excuse the pun.

1. Two years at Vogue: while the proper promotion is still TK (cannot tick this one off my "Resolutions list" yet!), I am designing quite a bit more, around 60 pages in the October issue...do what you will with that information. Hello major portfolio update! 2. Wakako is coming back to the city this weekend. 3. Loads of art-stuff happening this Friday and thru the weekend, nearly all of it in Brooklyn. I find that, since the West Chelsea gallery district has gone to sleep for the summer, much of my art-goings-on have occurred in Brooklyn. Mostly Bushwick, Greenpoint, Williamsburg, and around the Gowanus Canal (so Carroll Gardens?)...must add DUMBO to the list. 4. Still have not made it to the beach...

Last night I participated in and experienced part of Bradley Eros' multimedia marathon at ISSUE on the Gowanus Canal. Titled "Little DreamO in Slumberland", the 12-hour masterwork (co-curated by myriad audio, video, performance artists and other creatives) was pared into one-hour segments that revolved around the walls of the silo space, like the movement of the zodiac. We were promised a range of expressions, from the sonambulant to the tittilating to the delicious. I had heard about this show almost two weeks ago through my friend and coworker Nick* (who had a video piece somewhere in there) and had promised to take Wakako. We mutually fell in love with Bradley Eros after witnessing his mesmerizing mushroom-eating performance at Monkeytown and could not wait for an entire night organized by him. Long story short: Wakako was unable to make it. A family emergency forced her to return to Japan and, due to the convoluted American visa system, she is facing the unnecessarily arduous task of returning to the States. There, I wrote it. I really miss her and missed experiencing this night with her, but I knew I had to do it. With that in mind, I showed up at the Gowanus Canal around dusk last evening, as the air cooled over the Brooklyn industrial area. Nick and his boyfriend Brock met me near the gate, introduced me around, and informed me that the show was about to begin. I ducked inside for a beer (another cup of that Sweet Action) and I spied two little girls in PJs and fuzzy slippers lounging outside the bathroom. They had to be the Street daughters, Maya (the blond) and Noa (the little brunette) who were to perform in the first segment with their father Mark, reading bedtime stories. Eros passed me in the hall, clad in a burgundy silk dressing gown and loafers, and I thought to myself that this would be a magical night. Upstairs, as the room filled, several guys moved chairs and repositioned equipment. The 8 p.m. start time had come and passed, yet still they fiddled with placement and connections. One of them turned to the crowd and said "this is the Jack Smith part of the performance...all setting up and no show." We laughed and I secretly thought: YES I am definitely meant to be here. Then Eros took the floor, welcoming us, the chimes of the first sign of the zodiac (Aquarius in this case) sounded and the show began: 1. Bedtime Stories and Dream Sequences: Mark Street and his daughters sat and he read by the light of a lamp, in front of a screen blasting abstract nature footage. I moved to a rug in front of them, joining Nick, Brock, and several other performers (Chika Iijima, Zach Layton, and Marie Losier). The reading was a nice amuse, preparing our palates and brainstems for whatever lay ahead, but little Noa truly brought the house down when she grabbed a large book from her dad, Cinderella and Cinderedna (is this the title? About a far more worldly poor girl who can play the accordian and takes the city bus to the dance), and proceeded to enchant us with a reading. 2. Pulsating Drone: Zach Layton picked up his guitar and, with assistance from Ray Sweeten on a Roland and two other guys on laptops, brought a sweet swell of reverb across the room. The drowsy act was complex and emotive, dragging out so many chords that I couldn't believe it was all emanating from a guitar. Some of those around me drifted off on the rug, lost in the moment. 3. Dreams, Visions, Mythologies: Nick's act, a presentation of "The Getty Address: An Opera About Don Henley" (of the Eagles!!) kicked us further down the rabbit hole. How to explain? It's animated by James Sumner (Anna Films) in a vaguely retro video-game-ish, hand-painted sort of way, 2D yet multilayered in a 3D way. The music, a pounding, organic soundtrack that would sound like mid- to late-90s Future Sound of London if not for the Don Henley singing, was composed by Dave Longstreth (Dirty Projectors), who also played the part of Henley. And what was it? A quest, an odyssey, through a rainforest, Aztec temples, prehistoric times, modern times, Edo-period Japan, the Civil War, and featuring a cast of singing jungle birds, ibises, kung fu kangaroos, walking beetles, huge Aztec spiders, dangerous truckdrivers, and Bidisha Bannerjee as Sacajawea. Did I miss anything? Oh yeah, and Don Henley playing his guitar. It felt like a huge yet ultimately harmless acid trip. Exhilarating. My heart throbbed in my chest during certain sequences and I caught myself holding my breath. Even surrounded by veterans of this video art circuit, I knew I wasn't the only one thinking "Nick, man, you're a genius, but where did you find these guys??" I wholeheartedly urge you to check out this video (I think it's available online?). I caught up with Nick after his segment and expressed my enthusiasm as we got a bit of cool night air. Marie was going over the list of videos she'd planned for her segment a few hours later, including an experimental one from three years ago that apparently closely detailed her oral surgery after a collision shattered her jaw. Not to be missed, she said. Marianna Ellenberg, who would present a cadre of experimental feminist videos before her, was already worried that she'd have to cut since the show was running behind. The sudden sound of drones reminded us that, in whatever form, the show was still going on, and we retreated upstairs to: 4. Sleep Research Facility: in the darkened silo, Chika sprawled on the floor with her laptop, cueing up hypnotizing geometric images on the big screen. Around her, illuminated by their laptops, sat Andy Graydon and the guys, coaxing an extremely bottom-heavy, pulsating mass to accompany and contrast the visuals. I took my spot on the floor and watched as Zach picked up his guitar again and slowly began a deeper sequence that forced feedback into the mix. The show swelled from twinkling ambience to heavy noise in some parts, like waves crashing, and Chika labored away at an ever-complex visual sequence, as she and Zach began responding to each other. As the screen faded to black, I felt a sense of contentment. It was a good time for me to leave. Marianna was already setting up for her feminist video show and I didn't want to miss that, nor some of the other acts to follow (Maria Chavez was set to perform her turntable wizardry around 1:30 a.m. and I'd missed her at ISSUE once before, and of course Mr. Eros himself and his "Dreamsicle" segment), nor was I necessarily ready to leave this dreamlike place behind. I was in a room and on the grounds of an extremely avant-garde art community, and many of those in attendance were creative women my age. Wakako wasn't there so I could have really talked to any of them (and I did a little, mind you) but in the end I didn't. Maybe if she had been there we would have stayed the night, participated in the slumberland, had a slumber party of our own, who knows? I left the grounds and headed for the subway station with a handful of new acquaintances and budding creative friendships, people to look up again and see again, experience their art and share it with others. * a listage of web links follows (and I know I'll forget many, but if you are interested): Nick Hallett: Maison du Chic Chika Iijima: the VJ Zach Layton: his industries Ray Sweeten: Mitgang Audio Andy Graydon: Narrative Marie Losier: Filmmaker James Sumner: vs. Anna Films Dave Longstreth: Dirty Projectors

It's America's Independence Day, my third in NYC. And I wasn't going to spend it on the roof of a friend's place in the East Village, watching the gassy, loud fireworks over the water. Oh no, I am not one to follow traditions. Which is why I went to Monkeytown for and evening of Bowie, playing David Bowie's films on four screens simultaneously to a soundtrack of gamelan music! NICE. I joined an intimate gathering of either Bowie freaks or just unorthodox peeps like myself (including several Japanese girls, one whom I've met here before, and the greatest young couple: he with a 'fro-hawk, she with a mohawk and two kids, the boy with the makings of a faux-hawk and the girl with long curly hair) and I watched The Hunger on one screen and Labyrinth on two. We laughed out loud more than several times, and the shimmering gamelan soundtrack worked to offset the onscreen actions, keeping us guessing. Though I ended up watching some fireworks anyway...we were so near the water, amid the warehouses of western Williamsburg. So some of us ducked out after the first round of films (I think The Man Who Fell To Earth was starting up as I left) and stumbled down a few blocks to the water's edge, checking out the big luminous smoky explosions in the sky that signify celebration.

After watching A Snake of June and Marebito sequentially, I have concluded that, perhaps through a combo of looks and mannerism, my father bears striking appearance to Shinya Tsukamoto. It is regrettable that I don't have a photo of the old man to compare to the quirky cult director but, if you've seen the guy act (he's often the antagonist in nearly all his films), let alone direct, just take Tsukamoto and apply Czech features, and you'll perhaps get what I mean.
